Reviews.Content: This is my third kindle fire and I am impressed.  It's lightweight without feeling cheap.  I don't mind holding my tablet for hours while reading.  The fire hdx is very responsive and does not bog down with the more graphic intensive apps. I like the upgrades that have been implemented with the new OS.  The e-mail app is very much improved and I like that I can download some prime videos to view offline.  I have not explored everything available, but I am happy so far.  Well worth the price for upgrading my previous kindle fire 8.9 hd.  I have even used the mayday feature and they solved my issue!  My magazines on my newstand were closing when I tried reading them and Sue solved my problem very quickly.  Turned out there was an issue with my device registration.  I will continue to recommend and purchase amazon products.

Reviews.Title: Very enjoyable
Reviews.Author: Mary Theresa Martinez
Reviews.Content: My son had the Kindle Fire HD 7".  I had planned to just borrow his device for mobile reading.  I often find myself waiting for him to finish with an activity or work.  I had been using my smartphone, Android os, to read and play a few games.  However, the tiny screen was leading to major eyestrain.  I can read a paper book, but during the winter it is dark when I am waiting on him to finish work and I was running down the car battery to read, if I didn't use the phone.  There also were some issues with the Android os and the Kindle app, Amazon kindly fixed those, but the screen was still very small.With the latest sale price on the Kindle, I decided to go ahead and purchase one.  I had intended to purchase the Kindle Fire HDX 7", but after some encouragement from my son, I purchased the 8.9".  I was afraid the larger device would be awkward to tote around.  I was very wrong.  I am actually reading more since I purchased the HDX,  The device was fairly easy to set up.  I turned it on and signed in -- and it defaulted to mountain time zone.  I don't live there anymore and it was annoying to hunt to find where to change the time zone.  I ended up borrowing one of the Kindle guides and learned many interesting things about the device.The device is for me, most of the time, but I was pleased to find apps for studying for the GRE for my son who is a junior in college.  I also like the language apps which help us master correct pronunciation.Since I have a small iPod, I don't use the Kindle much for music, at least not yet.  It isn't portable enough to fit in my pocket when I exercise, therefore I cannot comment on the speakers.  We will likely use the device for watching Amazon prime movies, assuming the streaming doesn't eat up our internet allowance which is why we chose the larger size.  I also find the clarity of the screen and speed to be excellent.A few things I would like to see changed -- I read more than one book at once.  With this Kindle I can set more than one bookmark in a book, but I can't "name" the bookmarks -- one for where I'm reading, one for something of note....  I would also like to be able to have a tiny box or something to display the current time and battery icon when I am reading, or playing a game.  I know others won't want that, so I would like to see it be an option.I purchased the WiFi model because I could not afford 4G.  I am pleased that the device automatically connects to the WiFi devices it has "met" before, automatically.  One thing I learned early on, make certain to fully shut the device off to conserve battery power.  If used mostly for reading, the battery really will last 16 hours, or more, but only if fully shut down, in sleep mode it will continue to consume battery power.We don't watch much tv, although we love old movies.  We don't do social networks, I tend to be a more private person, so I wasn't certain if I could find enough uses to justify the Kindle purchase.  I was excited to find one of my favorite apps, Laudate available, and I can get an assortment of other theological resources easily.There are enough differences between the HD and the HDX that I am very happy I waited and purchased the faster and clearer device.  I do recommend a cover and if possible a padded bag for anyone who is as prone to dropping things as I am.  Actually, I have put my ID, credit card, and cell phone in the outside pocket of the padded bag and left everything else behind.  I purchased the set of 12 accessories at the same time I purchased the device.  The cover isn't fancy and if I use it often, I'll have to replace it within a year, but it is fine for now.I did not think I would like reading without the physical feel of a book in my hands.  Admittedly, I cannot close the book when I finish an electronic book with the same finality.  However, we already have 20 bookcases, very full, and I am reluctant to purchase more paper books without getting rid of some.  It will be so much easier to throw the Kindle in the vehicle and know I don't have to box up all the books included in it when my son head off to post-graduate work and studies!  I also love that I can change the font of the electronic books on days when my eyes are tired instead of digging out a stronger pair of reading glasses!I will next see how I like having the Kindle read to me, but that is another adventure.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful screen, good sound, a few  minor dislikes...
Reviews.Author: CMB
Reviews.Content: I'm a woman in my late 50's, computer savvy but not a techie, and I like electronic gadgets.  I thought long and hard about buying a tablet (do I really need one???), and then about which one to buy.  Based on reviews on both Amazon and other websites, I had a hard time deciding between the Google Nexus 7 (the 2013 model) and the Kindle Fire HDX.  After playing with both of them for about an hour in Staples, I decided on the Fire.  I was originally going to buy the smaller Fire but got the 8.9" because I wanted to use it to watch videos.I really like it very much.  I'm not into apps, so it doesn't matter to me that I don't have access to the Google (or Apple) app store.  I use the Fire mainly for surfing, checking emails, watching video and listening to music. The interface is easy to learn and use, and things move with lightning speed.  The Fire does have an absolutely beautiful screen which makes watching videos a pleasure (the picture is much better than my TV).  I haven't actually purchased any videos but have found lots of things I like in the streaming videos.  Of course, this thing is an Amazombie's delight - it's easy (maybe too easy) to access videos, books, my Kindle library, etc.  I think the speakers sound pretty good on their own, but I got a little Jam speaker and also some bluetooth headphones and love listening to music via Pandora or my iTunes library.Some minor complaints:  I understand that the Silk browser is improved on the HDX, but I absolutely don't understand why it doesn't support Flash.  It would be much more useful if it did.  I installed the Dolphin browser, and can play flash videos, but Dolphin acts a little twitchy on the Fire.  Also, there's no way to organize bookmarks in Silk (there is in Dolphin).I wish that I didn't need a smart TV in order to mirror the screen and watch videos on my TV, but it could be time for a new TV anyway.  However, I've read other reviews and people are generally disappointed about not being able to use a cable to connect their Kindle to a TV while traveling.  It's too bad this feature was removed, but I knew that when I bought it.It's really easy to set up email accounts, but there's no way to organize email other than the standard folders.  Also, there appears to be no way to select all messages so I can delete them - I have to go through and select them one by one.  I wouldn't want to have this as my only was to receive and send email.I've had a couple of Kindle e-readers, and I like reading on the dedicated e-reader better than reading on the Fire.  It's nice to have color and the back lit screen is good sometimes, but there's a lot of glare.  The 8.9" size is a bit heavy for reading.  I've had to get used to reading on it, and I still use my Kindle Touch a lot.In general I'm really pleased with the Kindle Fire, and I use it a lot rather than getting out my laptop.  Although as I said, I like gadgets, but I don't have a smart phone and the Fire is in between a smart phone and a laptop - very useful except for making phone calls!  I chose the Wi-Fi only version because I don't want to pay for a data plan, and it was great on a recent trip where there was Wi-Fi everywhere.  I didn't have to bring along the laptop but was able to have all my books, music, plus check out hotels etc. all in one small package.  I'm glad I bought the Fire but hope for some improvements in the software.

Reviews.Title: CROOKED
Reviews.Author: spongebob "book lover"
Reviews.Content: Bought this for Christmas  for almost $500 and had trouble with it freezing up. Had to return it. They sent another but it was used.So I end up with a used kindle for the new price. They don't credit anything to you for sending you a used kindle when you pay for a new one. I called but they did absolutely nothing. So I think it's very crooked to pay for a new kindle and get a used one. So  just letting people know to be careful because if you have to exchange it you will get a used kindle. Will not buy another electronic from amazon. Very disappointed with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Wonderful New Improvements
Reviews.Author: Annie "Annie"
Reviews.Content: I absolutely love the new front and rear cameras and all the new improvements.  I have a Kindle Fire HD, that I was very happy with, but with all the new improvements on the HDX, I just had to order it.  The processing speed is lightening fast, the picture and video quality is the best, and this almost replaces my laptop for functionality.  I purchased the MS Office app, and it allows me to view, edit, and print any of my office documents.  I also love that all my apps, books, music, etc can be downloaded onto any of my three Kindles.  When I looked at the Apple and Kindle comparison, I happily chose the Kindle.  I highly recommend the Kindle over any other brand.

Reviews.Title: Sooooo worth the wait!
Reviews.Author: L.L.
Reviews.Content: I really wanted the 8.9 fire last year but it lacked certain features that I really wanted so I purchased the cheapest 7" instead and decided to hold out until the 2013 version of the 8.9 with confidence that Amazon would have it right by then. I'm glad I did!First, delivery time was amazing. I ordered Friday night and to my surprise, it was delivered Saturday afternoon. This was my big gift to myself for this holiday season and I was expecting it to take a couple of weeks to get here like my previous Kindle orders. I'm still waiting on the cover as I decided not to go with the origami case after reading reviews of it being very heavy.As soon as I opened the box and had my precious in my hands, I knew I was right to wait for this version. It's exactly what I wanted. The weight is perfect, the rubber backing and beveling make it easy to hold at any angle.Turning it on with the new button in the back is a breeze. Once it was booted up I was ready to go. All of my apps were waiting to be downloaded from the cloud as well as all of my books and magazines. It took about 10 minutes to download all of them. Some apps aren't available yet for this model, like Draw Something but that's a developer issue, not a Kindle issue. The display is beautiful and crisp and the volume buttons are great. No more swiping down to adjust the volume while watching a video!I've synched two gmail accounts, one for work and one for personal use. I'm able to get notifications for both at the same time which is much easier than logging in and out or having to use two devices to get notifications for each. I've tested Picasso for drawing and the response to the stylus is incredible.I'm loving the side-bar swipe to access other apps while in use of another app instead of having to close out the current app to use another. If I'm watching a video on netflix or reading a book, I can quickly swipe to the side bar, check my email or look something up in wikipedia and then get back to my content.I love the rear camera, which was a big reason for holding out for this version. I've taken a few pictures, edited them on the tablet and shared with facebook from the editor with great ease. Videos are very nice and clear in HD and also very easily uploaded to facebook from the kindle. I would like to see some better video editors in the kindle apps but for now this is good.The processor is super fast, even with several apps open I've had no freeze ups or delays getting to content. Mostly, this is used for entertainment but now and then I need to do some work related stuff while I'm using it for entertainment. No problems at all with pausing a game, retrieving an email with a document, editing the doc, sending out and getting right back to my game.Lastly, battery life. I've been running Swagbucks videos on both the old Kindle Fire and the new one for the last 2.5 hours starting both with a full charge. The old Fire is at 70% now and the new one is at 80%. With the new one I've had it in constant use with games, videos and reading for more than 4 hours at a time without it getting below 56% charge. Including the PowerFast Charger with this Kindle was the cherry on top, it really does charge it fast!I have a lot of faith in Amazon as a company and was certain if I just waited it out another year they would have the tablet I wanted and I was right. Apple quality has been slipping in recent years as they seem more focused on new gimmicks to keep people lined up at their stores every year than quality. I think this tablet will hold it's value for a couple of years at least without feeling like I'm missing out if I don't upgrade it with each new version and that is also important to me. Well done Amazon, you didn't disappoint!

Reviews.Title: Deliciously Light
Reviews.Author: Alfonso Giordano
Reviews.Content: I had an iPad 1 until a friend stole it, never really used it much, never installed many apps, I'm just not an app or game guy.  I prefer using desktop computers (Mac Pro) and real televisions (60" LG 3dtv.)  I have a Kindle 2, Kindle with keyboard, & Kindle Paperwhite for reading (besides tons of real books).  This is the first tablet I'm really using and yes it is for consuming content and buying stuff on Amazon.  It really makes it easy to do so... I'm very so much impressed.  I'll actually watch video on this and the "second screen" functionality works great with my ps3 (that I pretty much only use as a media and blu-ray player.)  I use this tablet everyday, it is as light as light.  I don't care about Google Play or google apps, I'm not using this for productivity or travel.  I would like a VUDU or UV app since I have about a hundred movies on there (Flixster doesn't show them all) otherwise I'm satisfied.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Kindle Fire HDX 8.9"
Reviews.Author: Hattie Belle "Chime"
Reviews.Content: I love the visual qualities, clarity, color; watching videos is a pleasure. I used the live help service once, and it was so satisfying that I felt like a pampered customer. There are other great features and, in addition I am a long-time Amazon fan

Reviews.Title: Better and better!
Reviews.Author: Theodora "OH3"
Reviews.Content: Delighted with this wonderful new Kindle Fire!  Amazingly light and thin, beautiful high def, smooth and fast performance.  The 8.9" size is fantastic.  Rivals iPad in many ways.  Going from the original Kindle Fire to this one is remarkable.  Amazon is making Kindles better and better!

Reviews.Title: A huge improvement over the previous, outstanding version and (please don't hate me) preferred to our iPad5
Reviews.Author: Bob Tobias "Robert Tobias"
Reviews.Content: Quick summary:Pros: - Price - The Mayday feature.  Not for "us", of course.  See the details below for the details. - There are (really useful) apps which you cannot get on an iPad - Price :)Cons: - Not an iPadQuick Bottom Line:  If you want a great, versatile tablet then get this and save some money.  If you need an iPad then get that.Now some details; let's start with a comparison...Size (and weight) (different and may now) matter - This larger version of the Kindle Fire is much smaller, a tiny bit thicker, and a tad lighter than the iPad 5 Air. Of course that means the screen is a bit smaller too, about an inch.  Frankly, from using the previous versions of both  devices, which had similar physical dimensions, everything is close enough to not really matter a lot.Speed - About the same when doing similar activities side-by-side.  Same for wireless down/upload speeds.Available apps.  There are a lot more apps available of the iPad.  Again from personal experience, there are enough of any type available for the Kindle Fire that I can always find one (or more) that I like.  After that, how many note taking apps (for example) do I need?THERE ARE SOME apps available for the Kindle (and android in general) that are not available for the iPad.  One that I use, which for some IS REASON ENOUGH to choose a Kindle, is "WiFi Analyzer".Price - Another tiny difference is that the Fire costs hundreds of dollars less than a similarly configured iPad.  This can matter a lot if none of the other differences do.The May Day Feature - I have friends who bought iPads for their technically challenged, typically older, relativeness.  The intent was to provide a foolproof platform for access to email and those internets.  Sometimes it worked, and sometimes it didn't.  When it didn't getting problems resolved could be difficult since Grandma wasn't always willing to head out to the local Genus bar.  With this feature, the bar come to her.  Kidding aside, it positions this as the gift device of choice for anyone who might feel threatened with alternative tablets.Now for some specifics about this device: - The Ads supported version - They never get in the way.  As with previous versions, for me it is worth saving some money. - Display:  The display is outstanding!  Even better than the previous version, clear and bright without making everything look like a comic book and shows up well in sunlight without having to turn the display way up (which means the battery won't drain quickly). - Usability:  I've grown to prefer the Kindle interface, compared to the iPad or "Native" android tablets. The Kindle prominently displays apps used most recently and the ones I just installed in a side scrolling "Carousel". Other apps are just a few taps away. That's great for me and greater still for my young daughter ssince there's no hunting for the things I'm likely to want the most. The iPhone and other Androids I've seen do it the other way around. - First use: First use was very straightforward. I liked that it knew my name without me having to tell it. First thing it did, after greeting me (by name) was ask for my WiFi password. Once I logged it, it already knew about the apps, music, books, and videos I am using on my other Kindle devices.  I realize iPad does something similar. However, having used both, I feel the Kindle is easier. -On the business side, the built-in office software is handy and saves me from having to buy it outright.  I can access my email accounts, including those in an Exchange server, with no problems. Attachments, including .PDF files, Word documents, and Excel spreadsheets can all be read with no problems. - Back to the fun stuff, YouTube, Netflix, and SmugMug videos stream flawlessly. Pandora provides music without a hitch. It connects to Bluetooth devices quickly and easily. - The Camera:  The front facing camera, designed for video conferencing, provides a clear image while the screen provides a vivid image of the person at the other end. We ran some side-by-side tests with our iPad 3 and the Fire always performed better. They've added a rear-facing camera which I probably won't use for taking snapshots (that's what an iPhone is for) and will for Skype sessions where I want to show my surrounds. - The Missing Charger: Isn't missing this time.  In the past Amazon didn't include on, probably figuring by this time most people already had *something* capable of charging their latest device and would prefer to save a couple bucks.  This time they tossed one in.  Still, if you haven't sprung for a Bolse® 4 Port High Output Charger buy now, you're missing out.

Reviews.Title: Better than any tablet on the market!
Reviews.Author: Nigel
Reviews.Content: The best Kindle ever.  It does everything that has been advertised and more.  I love, love, love it - for someone who does not easily learn how to operate electronic items this was as easy as 1,2,3.  Thank you Amazon for a great product!!

Reviews.Title: Not an Android tablet - very limited
Reviews.Author: R. Precourt
Reviews.Content: I recommended the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 to my uncle who wanted a tablet just for basic stuff like e-mail, web browsing, Skype, etc.  I thought this one may be the best fit for him because he is not very tech savy and always asking me for help with his computer.  The 'Mayday' feature was the tipping point over other tablets as he could get assistance right on the device.I ordered the device for him and had it shipped to myself for setup and planned to ship it out to him, along with a wi-fi router already configured to it.  While performing the initial setup I quickly realized that this was not going to be a good fit at all, dispite the Mayday feature.  Here are my observations.The first problem I ran into was that the Kindle OS is VERY limited on settings compared to any other Android device that I've used (and I've used many over many years.)  The first thing I wanted to change was font size as he is older and would have difficulty reading the extremely small print size and found that there are only two settings for font size (normal and large, which isn't much larger than normal.)  On some screens it's acceptable, but on others it's still SO small, like the registration page for example.  It does have a 'magnifier' setting, but that is a pain to use as you have to pan around the screen to see everything with two figner swipes.  All my other Android devices have five (5) different font size choices, allowing easy reading of the entire screen at one time.  I found the limitation of settings options to be the case throughout the device menus - very few customization settings options.The second big problem which was the deal breaker is that you MUST provide credit card information, address, etc in order to download FREE apps.  I confirmed this with a rep over the Mayday feature, which I must say does work flawlessly.  My uncle did not want to provide this information as he never plans on downloading anything that would cost him, as he will only be using this for basic things.No flash support at all, at least out of the box.  I know this can be an issue on other tablets, like iPad especially, however, I could not get any videos to play on the Kindle Fire at all, not even YouTube, which generally will work on any other tablet I've owned.  Couldn't try downloading any other browsers or apps due to the need for a credit card to download free apps.At this point I gave up and decided to return it and get him the Galaxy Tab 3 10.1 instead, as it is a full featured Android tablet and won't require him to provide credit card information to download free apps from the Google play store.In all fairness, I realize this device might not be designed to be a full featured tablet, but I was hoping for more and did not expect it to be locked down so much.There are good things about it though, if you can deal with the other shortcomings.  The screen is amazing!  The sound quality is also very good.  It's lightweight and seems to run pretty fast (although I really couldn't do much with it to explore that.)  The Mayday feature is great also!  The camera takes good pictures, although it seems to take a long time to focus.If you are a Kindle user and want a device for that purpose this is a great product that goes beyond the basic Kindle experience.  If you're looking for a more robust Android tablet you may want to look at some of the other choices out there.

Reviews.Title: Very disappointed...Read the return policy
Reviews.Author: Rosalie Buck "CHESSNUT"
Reviews.Content: The device I purchased in January would not connect to wireless or update my email unless I powered down 2 to 3 times a day. I spoke with Mayday , customer support and the tech team several times over a period of about 5 weeks. No one helped or was able to resolve the problem. Finally I was told that Amazon was aware of this particular problem with other devices and a software update would fix the problem. It was not fixed. I was told a replacement would likely have the same problem, so I decided to return the Kindle as well as the case (which will only fit the Kindle).I paid $523.99 for the Kindle and case. I have been refunded $371.20 due to a RESTOCKING fee of $92.80 ... I do hope they don't sell this particular device to someone else...There were other deductions as well as a denial for a refund for the case because I returned it after the 30 days allowed...my attempts to have the Amazon team resolve my problem took too long to benefit me in any way I guess.It's been disappointing.I'm going to the Apple Store............

Reviews.Title: Awesome tablet if you're ok with having JUST Amazon right out of the box....
Reviews.Author: drEville
Reviews.Content: To preface, this was my very first tablet but I'm at the very least a tech enthusiast so I wanted to know full well what I was getting into when I had purchased this.I wanted a tablet for media consumption first and foremost but the option to do light office work if need be as well. Nothing too in depth just some basic office apps. I also would like to have a tablet that I could sync with my Android phone but that wasn't a deal breaker, I could live without that option.I was contemplating this tablet or the Nexus 7, Asus Memo FHD 10" tablet, or a Samsung one. Well the Nexus 7 screen was too small for me especially when watching Netflix or movies but was awesome for gaming. The Samsung tablets were surprisingly expensive when compared to other tablets that offered more in terms of screen display, speed, and functionality (I think my biggest dismay with Samsung is their Touchwhiz overlay. I mean it's good when it works but it sucks when it doesn't, I have a Galaxy S4.) I didn't like the size of the 10" tablets, so I thought an 8-9" tablet would be a good compromise and it turned out to be the perfect size range for me.Now I knew that the Kindles come with an Amazon skin, Mojito 3.0 OS as they like to call it, on all their hdx tablets and this works well....for the most part, depending on what type of person you are with a tablet. Now onto the positives and negatives.I'll touch first on the positives, IMHO.-The screen is fantastic. The colors "pop" out and really are vibrant. What's even better is the battery life paired with this is phenomenal, at least in my usage. (I'll touch on this a little later.) You can really tell that they had put some time and effort into making the screen one of the best. I think it really shows the ingenuity of how well they were able to push a wonderfully looking screen. The PPI is almost absurd, 339, with a resolution of 2560 x 1600. Incredible, especially when Apple's own Ipad Air has this; 2048 x 1536 resolution at 264 pixels per inch (ppi). Kudos to you Amazon for making such a wonderful and beautiful display. Oh, and having 100% sRGB color accuracy helps with making all the images and colors shine and pop out. All my movies and shows really looked astounding in low or high lighting. Touch reaction was spot on, no lag. Everything was very responsive and concise. Very impressive screen.-The speakers.....oh my the speakers. They too are awesome. When I had first turned on my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9", my gf almost didn't believe the sound was coming from a tablet! The sound is fantastic, not the absolute best, but close to it. You can really hear the Dolby Digital from within these speakers. The highs and mids are great while the lows are discernable enough to make them sound as they should, given what speakers they're coming from. Even on the highest volume setting, the sound was still clear and crisp. It didn't sound muffled or reduced as you would hear in some speakers. TBH, I never tried the listening through the headphones so I can't comment on that, sorry.-The battery. Very impressive, imo. I had used my tablet for an avg. day, 4-6 hrs with mostly gaming and watching videos, some light reading (Had the Amazon Prime Free trial membership while had my Kindle Fire hdx.) The brightness was always set to auto. I didn't have any email setup so never had to push notify there. So specifically speaking, I used this tablet strictly for watching videos and playing games, while doing some light reading. I would charge my tablet about once every 3-4 days. The charge time was always brief, never going over a few hours, charged just as fast if not faster than my Galaxy s4. Battery was impressive with my usage.-Speed. Not much to comment here other than it was super fast! It's the only tablet I've seen so far that changes orientation from landscape to portrait INSTANTLY. I mean instantly, no lag whatsoever. It was nice. With a quad core Snapdragon 800 on 2.2 GHz Krait 400, it flies. Add to boot it has an Andreno 330 GPU and 2gb of ram, it has the latest and greatest processing power at this time. It definitely showed when playing games or multitasking. Apps loaded with ease, everything was super responsive, no lag whatsoever that I had encountered.-Cameras. I opted for the 32g version as I wasn't sure how much of personal content I was going to add on here. I never used the camera other than for a test. I like the fact that the HDX 8.9" version has a LED back flash and an overall better camera on it than the HDX 7" but it's really not needed but nice to have, for me it wasn't necessary. To note, the HDX 8.9" has both a front and rear facing camera with a LED flash on the back. I add this to my positives b.c even though it's not really necessary to have a camera on a tablet it's nice to have "just in case".-Size. The overall dimensions of this tablet are great. It's actually pretty light and not at all bulky or thick. The dimensions are what is expected in this day and age for top end tablets. Unless you tack on the Amazon made and endorsed Origami case onto it which adds almost double the weight. It surely protects but it adds a considerable amount of bulk.-Having Amazon Prime. If you're already a member or thinking of becoming one then an Amazon Kindle is the way to go if you want a tablet. It offers a bundle of advantages to Kindle Fire owners when they also have Prime, it's a great service. However, in recent days I've read and heard they are looking to increase the price of Amazon Prime because of shipping costs (2 day free shipping is included in Prime.) and the like but I guess that's still in the talks and perhaps their may not be a price hike after all? Hope not. :)  You get to borrow one book/mo from their extensive library, you have access to their Prime video library (I honestly think Netflix is better but to each their own.), and other nice features as well.Negatives-Tied exclusively to Amazon...Now before I say anything else, some people may view this as a positive but again, I said these were IMHO. I know you could root and flash to another ROM but outside the box you're stuck with just Amazon and their regulated ecosystem. (Some people don't want to take the risk of voiding their warranty or bricking their devices just to get it to run an Android rom or the like. I understand that it can be a simple process but sometimes the risk doesn't negate the end result for some.) I didn't think much of it initially but as the days went by I was becoming more envious of not having the Play store. I bought this tablet mainly for media consumption so I had hoped I would be set on what Amazon provided...I was. For a bit. I liked the idea that Amazon has "coins" you can purchase for a discounted price in which you can use anywhere in their mobile store. The Amazon store is good but if you're looking for game or other entertainment apps then the Play or App store is the way to go.-No external sd card port. I know that with the newer versions of Android most apps and games you can't transfer to the sd card but knowing it's there in case you want to save personal music, vids, or pics, is nice to know. I will say in the Kindle Fire HDX's defense it has a nice cloud based server to "drop" things into but at this moment I'm not completely sold on the "cloud" universe yet. Time will tell.-Read up on some current Fire HDX owners complaining about their power adapter plug-in port becoming loose or outright breaking. I don't want to scare anyone but please be forewarned that this is an issue, how big or small Idk but it was one of the top complaints when I did my research. I was leery myself b.c the way the charger adapter plugs in is very odd and can easily seeing it being broken or malfunctioning in the future and the incidents where people had notified Amazon about it, well that's another story. It plugs in at an angle slighted towards up. It's kind of odd that it would plug in at an angle and not level with the tablet. It looks very wonky, imo. With my luck, the charging port would break a day after the warranty, lol.OVERALLIf you shop Amazon frequently, or have Amazon Prime, plan on getting it, or want a tablet that's easy to use comparatively (Mayday button is a great feature for noobies and the like.) then this tablet is for you. If this tablet had the option to either have the Amazon store or the Play store downloaded right out of the box then I would've downloaded the Play Store and would have kept my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9"  I honestly couldn't take having a "locked" down app store but again to each their own. I like having Google Voice, Maps, Gmail, etc right out the box. So instead of keeping my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9", I had replaced it with the LG G pad 8.3" tablet and my the differences. It's almost night and day even though they are both running Android technically. I will be writing a review for that tablet once I get to know all the nuances with that one.But overall the Kindle Fire HDX 8.9" is an AWESOME tablet. It's just I, myself, didn't like having just the Amazon store and no direct access to the Play store especially when I had purchased some apps from there on my Galaxy s4. I would highly recommend this tablet it you're looking to use it to read, watch movies, and some other light entertainment activities.For gaming and productivity I would undoubtedly recommend an Android, Windows, or Apple tablet.Happy shopping and thanks for reading my take on the Amazon Kindle Fired HDX 8.("

Reviews.Title: I know I made the best decision on this product
Reviews.Author: Iris McElroy
Reviews.Content: After reviews from many sources, I choose to purchase another Kindle Fire HDX. This is my 3 kindle product. The first was the reader, then the Fire 7" and now I'm sold on the HDX 8.9". I highly recommend this product because of the price, quality, and it has all that I need to make me happy. The product stands on it own. I donated my 7" Fire to a senior who is enjoying her first toy of the 21 century. The quality of the color, sound and pictures are excellent. A well invested product.

Reviews.Title: Great!!
Reviews.Author: Alberto Barraza
Reviews.Content: Will be purchasing this soon - amazing Trial experience. In my opinion it is better than the IPAD.The camera is amazing!

Reviews.Title: A WINNER!
Reviews.Author: Don McKeefery "micker61"
Reviews.Content: I have been shopping for a new "device" to replace my Kindle DX.  I was looking for something with more versatility, and that fits my lifestyle.  This is it!The screen resolution is superb!  The size is just right!  And, the features are spot on!I spent a few hours setting it up and loading on some familiar apps, as well as some new ones.  I found the ease of locating and loading to be intuitive.  In fact, everything about the device seems intuitive...which is something that concerned me at first since it is more than just an e-reader!Did I mention the blazing speed?  It's as if the device is reading my mind and is already queuing the next app that I want to open and use.  You no sooner touch the screen and your app is open and ready for use!  This concerned me with some of the other devices I looked at.  Blazing fast!!I would, and will, recommend this device to everyone who is looking for a feature-rich device.

Reviews.Title: i'm glad i bought it.
Reviews.Author: garyhere "garyhere"
Reviews.Content: i'm a 65 year old computer literate, but a smart phone android Luddite. i am pleased with this tablet. i had a fire hd last year i sent back because i was not happy with the performance. this is totally different. it is fast! almost as fast as my hard wired desktop. the touch screen is accurate. i don't think i've had to double tap anything. it activates the wanted icon and not the icon next to the one you want. all apps seem to operate smoothly, though i mostly use it for reading. the reading screen is adequate and, other then some glare, it is easy on the eyes. the browser is really quick. i use it mostly for reading and checking the web for questions i have about anything that comes up. the battery lasts forever. i have never run it down past 50% even after 8 hours of mixed use. while reading it seems to use almost no power. the screen is the best i've ever seen on any tablet. AND IT"S LIGHT!!! it weighs less than half of what my 7 inch original fire weighs. easy to hold and read for hours. the miracast works seamlessly without any digital skip or sound delay on netflicks and youtube. why not five stars? the mail app does not let you "select all" and delete more than one email at a time. there are a few other minor software glitches that i presume will be fixed. when downloading from usb to documents file as instructed i get a message that i can't download to that location, but when i reopen the unit the download shows up? . bottom line i'm glad i bought it.

Reviews.Title: Loving this so far!
Reviews.Author: Shrubbin Cole
Reviews.Content: I've been playing around with this tablet for about 2 or three weeks now!I love it so far, it's so light and portable compared to my other devices!PRO: Really good video quality and image quality --surprisingly nice back AND front camera o-o - lighter than my coworkers iPad air, what? o.o-- Built in surround sound on such a thin device? Super impressive. I was about to download and play movies with no issues for a 7 hour trip without the device dying. O.o -  Good for entertainment value: there's instant downloads of any amazon instant streaming device! There's also local storage.-- very responsive, not laggy, easy to learn and pick up-instant unlimited tech support that can annotate your screen to show you how to use the device-comes with free perks from amazon wish coins so you get some free credit--easy to sync across platforms! (You can do it via USB or there's Kindle syncing programs)--Battery lasts surprisingly long! I left it out for a few days and didn't bring it with me to school or to workand the device would still be on! If only my phone could last more than 5 hours...--This is running MOJITO which is android based and I'm really surprised how easy everything is to set up. No syncing issues, no email issues, i only had one issue with the cloud but logging out and logging back in worked. (hah)Cons--Limited app market (a lot of normally free apps don't exist, or are third party...) the most common ones are there like Facebook, Evernote, and Skype is Built in!-- NO SD? :( No expanded storage, but there's tons of streaming services.-- No Timer on the camera? I guess I need a third party app, but I actually use this feature a lot. >.<--Silk? I couldn't find dolphin in the store if it runs android... but it looks like it's getting updates. It's usability is a bit limited but you can do bookmarks, tabs, and all that stuff. It gets stuff done!--this is insignificant but is it really remarkable that the product comes with the charger?-- No Chromecast support! I wasn't able to set it up with an AppleTV either. :\Amazon's working on this device but they're definitely going in the right direction. :) It's a great entertainment device that's worth the value!To be honest is this item is not towards my demographic (I use network services and need a productive tablet, having only open office with limited interal storage and dropbox kinda scares me.) but all of my relatives love it!I'm keeping it anyway for my  parents as they picked it up right away. :) Even if I'm not home, the mayday button can show them how to do the same things!

Reviews.Title: Its My Best Friend, sorta
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Have loved all my Kindles and love this too.  The clarity of the screen is AAA rated.  So sharp.  I haven't tried the SOS yet but nice to know its there.  Love the speed of the processor and its ease of picking up wifi signals.  My only complaints are that they left off the mini HDMI port and I had just bought a cable to use it for my previous Kindle HD.  I had to buy another device and cable to make use of the mirroring to a TV screen to watch my Prime shows.  Also the buttons on the back rather than the edge make it quite inconvenient when you have a case/cover for your device and the front flap is open and wrapped around the back.  Come on Amazon/Kindle.  Run this stuff past some test people!  Overall though, you couldn't pry it out of my hands.

Reviews.Title: Love my Kindle
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I love my Kindle HDX 8.9.  I have the original Kindle Fire 7" to compare it to.The only problem I'm having with the HDX 8.9 is that it doesn't hold a charge for long.  The first one I ordered came and was fine for 3 weeks and then I started using the camera and had the pictures on the carousel.  Then the battery would drain even while just sitting and not being used overnight or in the daytime.  It will drop 50% just sitting there asleep.Amazon replaced the first one with another HDX 8.9 and it seems to do the same.Issues seemed to begin when I started using the camera and having pictures on it.Now I don't keep any pics on the carousel and it helps but doesn't solve the problem.Battery does not hold a charge no matter what I do.  I only use it for short periods of time through the day, do not play games and don't Skype or anything.  Probably at the most 1.5 a day total and the battery drops about 50%.Otherwise I love my Kindle HDX for ease and convenience.Only wish the battery would hold a charge longer.  I can't imagine it lasting the 10 hours that they are talking about when using it.  It drains just sitting doing nothing.

Reviews.Title: Superb!
Reviews.Author: MarkMT
Reviews.Content: I've now had my HDX 8.9 for a month and after a couple of little hiccups I'm totally loving it. The screen is gorgeous, the user interface is very easy to use, the speed of the device is very snappy, it charges pretty quickly with the wall charger provided and the apps I'm using are great.In the first few days I had a problem with the device spontaneously rebooting and I was NOT happy. But a few days later Amazon pushed out a software update and about a day later I had a weird issue that led me to doing a factory reset. I'm not sure whether the original problem was with the Fire software or perhaps a rogue app I had installed, but everything is working fine now and I couldn't be happier.---Update: this review has apparently been classified with the 16GB Fire HDX 8.9, but I actually have the 64GB version. As I said, I couldn't be happier. I am also glad that I got the 64GB version - I initially started downloading movies at the top resolution (1080p I think) and it actually didn't take me too long to run out of storage after less than half a dozen downloads. I'm now using the medium quality (720p), which is perfectly fine and typically 2-2.5GB each.

Reviews.Title: THIS IS MY NEW BEST FRIEND!
Reviews.Author: terry lanning
Reviews.Content: I have never been much of a tech person but  I don't leave home without my Kindle.  In this world of hurry up and wait it is so very nice to always have something to occupy your time.  I can read, play games, check my e-mail or watch a movie or tv show that I missed.  You can't beat the picture quality, well worth the price.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding product
Reviews.Author: Chad Simons
Reviews.Content: Kindle Fire HDX 8.9", HDX Display, Wi-Fi, 16 GB - Includes Special OffersI've bought a new Kindle each year for 3 years.  I've not replaced any because of problems but wanted the newer features.  The very first one I purchased still works perfectly and is a great product.  The improvements each year have been substantial and very much worth the price.  The ease of setup and quality of the product will keep me and my children Kindle owners.  Last years 8.9 HD I thought would be hard to beat but the new HDX is just amazing.  Smaller, lighter, much more powerful and the display has to be seen to be believed.  I'm a computer geek with pretty discerning taste but the Kindle's do everything better then expected.

Reviews.Title: Wow!
Reviews.Author: Mary Jordan
Reviews.Content: This tablet is great. Super fast and very easy to use. Great product and a reasonable price for what you get.

Reviews.Title: Thumbs Up!
Reviews.Author: Jim Spencer
Reviews.Content: I have bought Kindles since the original DX unit came out. I think I am qualified to say, since I have purchased in excess of ten or more Kindles, that I can say just what kind of deal they are. Amazon has managed to take on the market with the introduction of the Kindle Fire, and have slowly refined them through the Kindle HD, to now with the Kindle Fire HDX. This unit is a grand leap in performance, as well as other refinements in the platform. It offers me everything I need in the way of utility, as well as entertainment and has also improved battery life significantly. No more, no less.

Reviews.Title: Kindle HDX
Reviews.Author: newbie
Reviews.Content: I 've had 3 Kindles including the HDFire and this is by far is the best.  Much longer battery life than the Fire, large screen so you can read one complete page before you have to flip and a little improvement in software over the HD Fire.  It is bigger to tote around but lighter so that makes it easier to use.  Overall I like it, it seems to get along with wifi even better than the other models, but still wish Kindle would let us create a folder where we can put our "read" books so they aren't always on the carousel or the book list-- just reduces the clutter a bit.  Not a lot of options for cases yet- but that will change.  Now for the apps writers to get busy.....Have not used the "Mayday" button yet but one of these lonely, long winter nights I might just tap it so I can chat with Amy:-)))

Reviews.Title: Fantastic
Reviews.Author: Jack Leffe
Reviews.Content: It is like having a Computer and Pad all in one and it is fast. The display is awesome & colorful.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet!
Reviews.Author: broncobutch
Reviews.Content: Fantastic!  I can't say enough good things about this tablet.  My first tablet and it is a winner.  I have used other tablets from relatives and they were good.  The Kindle fire HDX 8.9 runs smooth and is very easy to navigate.  Still discovering a lot of little things I didn't know about it but it is so much fun.  I am pleased that it came preloaded with youtube.com.  I am a Amazon Prime member.  Makes a big difference with movies and books.  Anyone on the fence about buying one don't hesitate.  Get it now.  You will see for yourself how nice they are.

Reviews.Title: I love our Kindle HDX
Reviews.Author: Robert S. Joy "Think only of good thoughts, a...
Reviews.Content: My 1st Tablet and very pleased. My wife and I went back and forth between other brands and glad that we stayed with the Kindle.We are still finding out how to fly with the Kindle as it's so powerful and rich with features, a new day brings forth new excitement and discovery.

Reviews.Title: Great video and sound - But still a tablet with limited functions
Reviews.Author: Jeff is Rad
Reviews.Content: Bought this tablet to replace my aging Toshiba Thrive. I knew early on that the Kindle HDX was not meant to be a full featured tablet like the Thrive and Nexus. But I was still disappointed at how much Amazon unnecessarily left out or disabled features that are common on Android tablets. The Mojito OS takes some getting used to even if you are accustomed to Android, not seeing a whole list of configuration options was a little jarring. But overall the HDX OS performed very smoothly.PROS:- Lightweight. About a third of what my Thrive tablet used to weigh.- Great display and video.- Sound was clear and crisp.- Nice case texture and screen. The back has a subtle rubber texture that makes it very easy and comfortable to hold. The screen is super smooth; it feels like you're moving your finger on an oily surface.- Painless E-Mail & Calendar Sync. I was able to connect my Google GMail account to the HDX's email client quickly and easily. However the email & calendar client are basic and limited in what they can show. For example my GMail Inbox message categories did not carry over into the HDX email client.- Speedy performance. I was able to stream Prime movies with no noticeable lag.- Connection to Amazon.com was seamless. When I took my HDX out of the box it recognized me right away and connected me to my account.- Mayday Tech Support. Really works as advertised. I was connected to a tech adviser in about 30 seconds. He was knowledgeable although he did misunderstand my initial problem and I had to interrupt to correct him.CONS:- Speech-to-Text(Voice Dictation). This is a new feature that was added in an update after my purchase. Is accurate but is noticeably slower than the voice recognition in other Android devices.- No GPS. I have read conflicting reports on whether or not the HDX has GPS or not. Either way using your HDX with GPS enabled apps is a no go.- No Haptic Feedback. It would've been nice to have a tablet that provided tactile feedback for text entry and games.- Bad photos with the Camera. My HDX took pics that were very grainy with inaccurate color. The photo options available for the HDX are also very limited. About the only things that you can change while taking a picture are the flash and panorama modes. You cannot adjust the white levels, spot metering, etc.- Limited personalization options. On my old Android tablet I like being able to organize my apps as I saw fit. Also I liked being able to change the wallpaper every now and them. There is no way to do these things with the HDX.At this point I'm torn on whether to keep my HDX or to return it. I like the idea of watching Prime Movies on a tablet even if I am not connected to the internet. However not having basic tablet functions is very frustrating. Also Amazon makes no promises that the problems will be addressed in the future. All I was told by Kindle Support was that a new update was coming soon. There was no comment about what exactly the update would contain, just that one was coming(!?!?)

Reviews.Title: Not Android Compatable
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Beautiful display, nice size, solid feel but......the Kindle HDX is Not a mainstream android Device.  I guess I missed the fact that Amazon is no longer Android when I made this purchase.  Big mistake!  These kindle devices apparently do not, will not load apps from Google play or anywhere else  BUT the Amazon store. Will not load any apps paid for in the past.  Very shut down and limited like an Apple product.  Very dissapointing for a company like Amazon to take such an obvious step BACKWARD!  Will return for refund.  Ouch!!! Purchased Galaxy Note 8.0 instead, very satisfied.

Reviews.Title: return policy not good
Reviews.Author: C "cbglacier"
Reviews.Content: I love my kindle but in less than one month a 1 inch long blue line appeared about 2 inches down from the top of the screen. I called amazon they said they would send me a new one. I asked if it would be a new one and they said yes. Instead they sent me a refurbished one. I don't like refurbished electronics when I bought a new one. Now I have to decide which one to keep.

Reviews.Title: Solid, but no iPad killer.
Reviews.Author: F. Sherman
Reviews.Content: Amazon sent me this tablet free for 30 days.  I was in the market for a new tablet anyway so this seemed like a perfect opportunity to test the kindle.  I own a first generation iPad retina already and I'm looking to possibly upgrade to the Air.  Amazon puts the Kindle HDX 8.9 directly against the Air.I will start the comparison with my current retina.  When I unpacked the HDX the first thing that stands out is the weight of the machine.  It's very light and comfortable to hold.  Seams appear tight, however the plastic housing feels a bit cheap.  No doubt they used the plastic to cut weight but it does not have a quality feel and I worry about it's durability.  Next I plugged the HDX in, the plug is either purposefully angled awkwardly up (I doubt it) or it's just poorly aligned when built.  The plug works, but it is not anywhere as smooth to plug as the lightning plug on my 5s and on the new air.  It's about as easy to plug as the old Apple 30 pin on my retina.Once it was fired up and ready to roll the home screen is fairly spartan.  I decided to open my Amazon cloud account and was pleasantly surprised to see all of my stuff there and waiting.  Your Amazon account is very nicely linked to HDX.  I pulled up BB King's "Live in Japan" on both the HDX and my Retina iPad and did some side by side audio.  There is no easy way to put this, the HDX is an audio dud with the external speakers.  the iPad was capable of getting much louder, clearer and better bass response.  I tried with both on flat hard surfaces and holding in hand.  I use the external speakers when I'm working on projects around the house and want some music around so this is a fairly important feature to me.  Next came the headphones test.  Both performed equally with my Klipsch S4i headphones and my Sennheiser over ear headphones.My Amazon prime streaming was very handy on the HDX.  Easy to access and I had zero issue streaming HD quality movies.When it comes to the screen it's a bit off a toss up between the Retina and the HDX.  The HDX is capable of a slightly sharper image thanks to the higher resolution but the Retina has better colors...The HDX display just looked dull.  Whites appeared with a distinct yellow tint and nothing seemed to pop off the screen. Try as I might, I could not get it to display colors as well as my Retina.  But again, the resolution is sharper on the HDX so you need to decide whats more important to you.  To me, the colors are far more important so I will say that I prefer the Retina display, slightly, but it's still my preference.In terms of general use.  I do not, at all, like the lay out of the HDX.  Simply finding things is much more of a chore compared to the iOS layout.  This might be more to do with the fact that I'm very accustomed to iOS, but I would like to think that a well laid out tablet is something that you can pick up and it feels great right away.  I never really had a learning curve on any iOS device, it was all fairly natural.  It's hard to blame Amazon here, ease of use is something Apple has been leading the industry on for a long time, but Amazon does have a long way to go to catch Apple here.Next I did some simple web browsing.  Silk on the HDX was VERY disappointing...It's a standard web browser, but it was not smooth at all.  Load times were twice that of my Retina and scrolling up and down pages was vert stuttered.  Safari on my Retina is very smooth and very quick.  Keep in mind this is a two year old machine.Besides Safari Vs. Silk, the Retina and HDX seemed to run at about the same pace, if not slightly quicker on the Retina.  Very upsetting considering the Retina by Apple terms is a slug now.  In all reality my 5s runs circles around the HDX.When I was visiting a friend that I know picked up a brand new Air, I brought the HDX with me to do a direct head to head.  Now that it's all said and done, Amazon has zero business comparing the HDX to anything Apple is producing today...The Air just blew the HDX out of the water in nearly every aspect.  Once again, the only thing the HDX had on the Air was the resolution.  The Air loaded everything faster, was snappy and smooth as butter.The HDX is lighter, but it's also a smaller screen...IF you consider the extra screen size, the weight difference is in my opinion a non factor.  Add to that the Air keeps that solid quality Apple feel with it's metal case.  I found the Air to feel very light and nearly as tiresome to hold as my Retina.With the Air everything that has bothered me about my Retina since the latest rollout of iOS is fixed.  Mainly my Retina is now a bit laggy.  Most notably when typing.  The HDX touchscreen keyboard was hands down the worst part of it.  Almost impossible to type on in my opinion.  Laggy and a lot of mistypes compared to my iPad and even my 5s.All in all, this is not a BAD product.  But to act like it competes with the Air is just down right false.If $400 is your MAX budget, I would go with the iPad Mini Retina all day long.  If you can swing the $500 for the Air, it's no contest.My advice to Amazon, continue to fine tune this thing.  The next generation NEEDS to be MUCH faster and the HDX screen must display better colors.Maybe in the future, but it's just not there yet to sway me away from from Apple.

Reviews.Title: Beats IPad by a mile! Amazon you have another hit on your hands with this new Kindle fire HDX 8.9"
Reviews.Author: D. Williams "Coyote Dave"
Reviews.Content: This is the best Kindle yet! I love my 7" kindle fire HD and use it all the time. However this Kindle fire HDX 8.9" is light and fast! And with the May day feature you can't go wrong! I just used it to get help setting up Skype. The personalized help and quick response I'm going to be spoiled! IPad look out! Way to go Amazon!

Reviews.Title: BEAUTIFUL
Reviews.Author: MTCUBED66
Reviews.Content: Just as good as my Kindle Fire HDX 7 inch. Perfect size for certain things that were  a little small on the 7 inch. Lightweight, excellent product. I would recommend you get the one with Special Offers. I have bought more than one thing because of seeing it on the special offers screen. They come up as screensavers sometimes on the unlock screen, or you can go to the top bar and scroll all the way over to view all special offers. The sound is very good quality, in fact it is better than my laptop sound. Good battery life, I can play apps all day on it. I would highly recommend this tablet. The Kindle also has great accessories available.

Reviews.Title: Great tablet with a ton of new features
Reviews.Author: James R Davis
Reviews.Content: There are a ton of different kinds of tablets and e-readers out there today and it's hard to know which one to buy. Some of them can have features you don't understand and sometimes they just all seem to be the same thing at different prices, so you don't know which one to pick. As someone who has had personal experience with several different tablets (and a couple e-readers), I would recommend this one. It comes with so many features and options that it may seem overwhelming at first, but it's definitely worth sifting through it all.The Kindle Fire HDX is designed with the user in mind and is built to help you do everything you would want to on a tablet. The Kindle has always had a pretty good display, but this one truly takes it to the next level. The images and colors pop out at you just as well as any good computer, and possibly better than some. They also gave us improved brightness settings and reduced the glare so you can use the tablet in bright lights or outside without blinding yourself or having to deal with those annoying bright spots.The performance is better than any Kindle before. In layman's terms, it works faster and better than ever before. Even so, it's very thin for easy holding and storage, but very durable, so it takes more to break it. It claims to have a 12 hour battery life, or 18 if you're just reading, but in my experience it can often stretch to around 20, depending on what you're doing.The two cameras, one on the front and one on the back, are excellent. The front camera offers a pretty clear picture. It's perfect for taking selfies or things like video calls with your friends or your boss. The read end camera takes amazing quality pictures and comes with a flash option so you can even use the camera in dark environment. The rear end camera also comes with several features and options which improve picture taking.The Kindle Fire HDX also has a new feature which they call the MayDay button. It's basically a help button that you can push at any time. It connects you to a live representative who can help you with any problem you're having with the Kindle. They're available at any time, for free. I've used the service a couple of times when I was confused about how to do something and they were great. They helped me fix my issue quickly and they were super polite. This feature may seem unnecessary but you won't think that when you end up needing it. You'll be glad that it's there and that you can use it for free!It comes with Prime Instant Video downloads. You have to already be an Amazon Prime member to use it, but once you are, this feature means that you can download any video from Amazon Prime to your tablet. Then you can watch it wherever you are, even if you don't have an internet connection. I use this to watch movies on long flights. It keeps me entertained and even helps me a bit with the sick feeling I usually get on planes.The tablet comes with a lot of new apps that can help you do the stuff that's important to you, like accessing your email and calender, plus a lot of other new apps to help your productivity. Of course, you can still install all the other apps that you might want to, just like with any other tablet.They've also added a new and improved operating system for this version, which they call Mojito. It starts with an Android base, but Amazon has added on a lot of their own stuff to make it more personal and easier to use for their customers. Mojito is completely customer oriented, so you're sure to love how convenient it is and what it can do for you.This tablet comes with a huge amount of other features that I can't possibly discuss here as thoroughly as they deserve to be. Beyond that, it has some options that are personalize at the time of purchase. They give you three options for the amount of storage you want - 16 GB, 32 GB, or 64 GB. I personally am using the 64 GB version, but if you're usually the tablet casually or just for reading, you can probably get away with a smaller amount of storage.They let you choose whether or not you want to see advertisements on your table (what they call special offers), and it's not that much more, so I would recommend getting the ad free version, but it's not that big of a deal if you don't want to pay extra for it.They also give you options about your internet connection. You can choose to get just Wi-fi, or you can get 4G LTE from either Verizon or AT&T.; I go through AT&T; and it's always worked perfectly for me. Pages load great and load time is nearly non-existent.You can also buy a 2 year warranty which includes accident protection. This isn't necessary, but I would recommend it, just in case something happens. Paying a little more to get the warranty is a lot cheaper than if the tablet breaks for whatever reason and you don't have any way to replace it. After all, buying a replacement tablet will cost far more than what you would pay for the warranty. It just makes sense when you do the math. You might also want to consider buying a case for it. I have one, and it helps me to keep it safe, plus it looks pretty cool.Overall, I would definitely recommend the Kindle Fire HDX, whether you're looking for a new tablet or just a simple e-reader. It has the features to be great for everybody. For more great electronics, check out http://www.amazon.com/b?_encoding=UTF8&site-redirect;=&node;=13900871&tag;=tabbooingcom-20&linkCode;=ur2&camp;=1789&creative;=9325

Reviews.Title: Not Bad, but I Miss Google
Reviews.Author: NuJoi "Create with me"
Reviews.Content: I like my new Kindle Fire HDX 8.9, but I'm not not in love with it. I've used the iPad, iPad mini and Blackberry Playbook, so I had a pretty good idea of what I wanted in a tablet. In the end, I narrowed it down to the Kindle Fire and iPad because I'm a member of Prime and I wanted to view Amazon streaming video on on a mobile device. Also, my favorite apps are not available for Android devices. I chose the Kindle Fire because of price and I know I will still one day get an iPad. So, the Fire is my iPad Mini. In terms of functionality, and I'll discuss this more below, the Fire is more reader and less tablet.With all that said, here's what I do love about the device -- it's a great value. The size is perfect for reading and I do love to hold it portrait style and read it like a book. If I feel really daring, I do so without the origami case so that I can appreciate how lightweight it is. The Amazon leather origami case is a really cool idea, but not great protection. Took me a day or so to get used to it. I do wish is was lighter and I wish I could get it in pink.I like the organization of my stuff -- carousel, home page/favorites and collections. I do have suggestions for improvements:1. I wish you could add web pages to the carousel2.  I wish the tablet would learn that just because I used something recently, I don't want it in the carousel.3.  I wish the collections could be for more than apps. For example, for my morning devotion time, I would love a collection that contained my gospel playlist, Bible reading apps and certain Kindle books.4.  There's no way to organize picturesMayday is so sweet. Although, I've realized that the help is really about technical issues, not bigger questions like why can't the device run Google apps. Still, this is an awesome feature if you a gifting the Fire to someone who is not tech savvy.As expected, the Amazon apps work great. I would like more visual notification to indicate which movies and TV shows that can be downloaded to the device. It should be just as easy to spot as the Prime indicator.The biggest disappointment with the Fire is no Google apps (as of January 1, 2014). This is why I consider the Fire more of a reader and less of a tablet. Without Google apps like Drive, Google Maps; YouTube and the full cadre of Android apps (like Instagram), this device fails to be a really serious workhorse. For those who use Chrome, you never realize how much you depend on it until it's gone. Don't be confused by the Google apps you see in the Amazon Appstore. These are workarounds developed by others; there are no Google apps, developed by Google, in the Appstore. You can sideload some Anddroid apps onto the Kindle (and I have done so for Instagram and PocketBible), but my point is that I shouldn't have to.If Google and Apple can find common ground, I simply don't understand why Amazon has to be so territorial with the Kindle. I'm wondering if this is the same marketing mistake Blackberry made with the Playbook; the marketplace has pretty much decided that we need two mobile operating systems, iOS and Android. I'm sure Amazon will say that developers have the option of putting versions of their apps in the Amazon App Store, but the fact that many haven't says something.Being forced to live without Google apps has forced me to discover a new favorite app -- Feedly, for blog reading. I've downloaded it to my Android and Apple devices.My next biggest issue with the Fire is the Special Offers. (I know I have the option of removing them for $15.) I'm complaining not because they are there, but because they are so 'untargeted' to me. Amazon has more than a decade of my purchasing history, wish lists, web data and tons of my reviews. Serve me ads for stuff you'd think I'd buy. I was expecting Special Offers to be so much better -- as good as recommendations on my Amazon.com homepage. The Special Offers are generally crappy because I have no interest in the products.Update 2/17/14: I have found a bug in the music playlists. I create my playlists on the cloud using my Kindle. I then dowload them to the device. All of the songs are already saved to the device before I download the playlist. However, songs will be missing from the downloaded playlist. The cloud version has 117 songs, the on-device version has three. Mayday and customer support gave me a solution. So, I uninstalled all music from the device and downloaded it all again from the cloud. I then downloaded the cloud playlists and the problem was solved -- for a few hours. Later, when I updated and created new cloud playlists; uninstalled the device playlists; and downloaded the cloud playlists again, songs were missing.Update 3/15,14: After weeks of back and forth, the issue above was resolved with a replacement Kindle. My cloud playlists loaded onto the device without a hitch. I haven't revised the cloud versions and tried to reload onto the device yet; no new songs have caught my ear. I have to say the getting the issue resolved left me very frustrated. Amazon's usually stellar customer service just didn't bring its A-game. I was so relieved when the rep I spoke with a week ago agreed to ship me another device. It took way too long to get to that solution.I find the speed to be slower than my iPhone and Galaxy phone.  I used all three while playing my favorite mobile game via Wi-Fi. When response time matters, I go for the iPhone instead of the Fire.My Fire has a problem connecting to free Wi-Fi. I haven't hit the Mayday button yet to figure out if it's something I'm doing wrong. The device will connect, but it takes a long while for it to tell you that you need to go to the provider's web page to agree to the terms and conditions. Opening the Silk browser yourself to get to the permissions page doesn't always work.I ordered the 16GB version based on other reviewers' comments regarding Prime movie and TV downloads. If I had it to do over again, I would have given more thought to the 32 GB because I have the Wi-Fi version. If I had gotten Wi-Fi+4G, 16 GB would have been just fine because I would have always had the connectivity to stream what I wanted to watch.All in all, the Fire isn't a bad purchase. I think how much you like it depends on what you're used to from other tablets and even your smartphone. It's a good value, but Amazon needs to rethink the relationship with Google. My user experience isn't as rich as it could be without more Android apps.

Reviews.Title: Definitely A Keeper!
Reviews.Author: Hal in Howell
Reviews.Content: I received my Kindle Fire HDX 8.9 last Thursday and I am very pleased.  It is SO fast compared to the Kindle Fire HD and lighter, too.  The HDX has a much more responsive touch screen and unmatched screen resolution.  WiFi set up was effortless. I was able to easily set up my various email accounts and download all the apps I used on the old KFHD including Netflix for video streaming (I also have Amazon Prime).  I side-loaded the Dolphin browser in order to view Flash videos (just like on my old HD).  Battery endurance seems very good and have run the HDX several hours at a time (I've not run the battery flat yet and recharge every morning).My only criticism of the HDX is the lack of the HDMI plug (I know, wireless is the future and all that, but I did like having it for travel where wireless video connection is just not available).  I'm holding on to my HD solely for the HDMI functionality.  This complaint is certainly not a deal killer.I've barely used the rear-facing camera (took just one photo to see if it worked and it does and the photo looked very good and I will be using it in the future). The rear-facing camera is a great addition and remedies my major complaint about the KFHD.The only real problem I've encountered with the HDX is that I'm unable to delete photos I downloaded from the Cloud (see updates below).  Enter the Mayday button.  I've got to say that Amazon's customer service is second to none (I guess it's part of their on-going plan for World Domination).  I pressed the Mayday button and I had a live CS person on-line within 15 seconds.  She attempted to fix the photo deletion problem without success.  However, she escalated the issue to a tech support person who, after going through several diagnostic procedures, wrote up a trouble ticket to pass on to the developers; all this taking place on-line (the problem is apparently unique).  A callback is scheduled for later this week.  The whole point of this story is to show how responsive Amazon is to customer problems.  BTW, the photo deletion issue in no way affects the functionality of my Kindle.I read just about all the 1-star reviews before purchasing and found few complaints that were credible (it seems that most of the negative reviews were by iPad fanboys or by those who just didn't know what they were talking about.  I invite you to read those reviews and see for yourself; they are quite entertaining in a perverse sort of way). The Kindle Fire HDX that I own is not the same HDX the 1-star reviewers were talking about.At the end of the day, the KFHDX is a superb device.  It is definitely not just an e-book reader.  I'm still discovering all that it can do.  I highly recommend it.I will update this review with the results of the Kindle problem mentioned above.*********Update January 3, 2014**********Received a callback from Amazon (on-time as promised) regarding the photo deletion problem.  The developers are stumped, but are still working on it.  There is supposed to be a new software update release in the next couple of weeks that may resolve the issue.  If that fails, we may try a factory reset (not my favorite solution as I'll have to reenter all my email settings, etc.).  If the reset fails Amazon will just send me a new device and I'll just start over.  I'm pleased with Amazon's efforts, though disappointed it may require a reset or de-registration or replacement of the Kindle.  At least the problem doesn't affect the Kindle's functionality in any way.  High marks to Amazon CS.  I still love the Kindle.  Further updates will be forthcoming.*********Update January 11, 2014*********I solved the photo deletion issue!  The problem was I was unable to delete photos.  The Kindle kept asking if I wanted to delete the photos from the Cloud (there were no photos on the Cloud).  I solved the problem by asking the Kindle to download the undeleteable (that's not a word, is it) photos from the Cloud even though there were no photos on the Cloud).  I could then delete them.  Apparently the Kindle got locked in some sort of loop and attempting to download non-existent photos broke the loop.  It took me awhile to figure it out, but it worked.  I'll have to let Kindle CS know about this.

Reviews.Title: Wow, this is a very nice tablet!
Reviews.Author: KG62
Reviews.Content: This was my Christmas present, I love it! The colors and the picture quality are sharp and crystal clear! I have never owned a tablet before so I don't have anything to compare it to.After figuring out where everything is,(not very hard at all) I have been having a lot of fun messing around playing with apps and games that were horrible and hard to see on my phone but oh-so-much-fun to play on this tablet! Even games I had downloaded for my little granddaughter are fun! :DUsing the cloud app I was able to send some of the pictures from my phone to the fire and the pictures look great! I tried out the camera as well and the picture quality was sharp and clear, I just had a harder time taking pictures using this, especially if I tried to zoom in on something. I'm sure once I use this more it will get easier. There are  picture editing functions built in too.I have tried streaming Amazon movies and YouTube videos. It  was easy, they played smoothly, and were excellent quality. The volume level and speakers actually sound better than my laptop. I think I am really liking this little machine! :)My books were easy to see in their collections, but I do like reading on my PaperWhite 2 better. I will use this more for cookbooks and magazines that have color pictures and save the rest of the book reading for my PaperWhite.I'm sure I will find even more things to love about my Kindle Fire as I discover the rest of the things it can do.

Reviews.Title: Long time Kindle Owner
Reviews.Author: Irene M. Dudley
Reviews.Content: I have had the Kindle DX (Bought a couple of times over thanks to a theft and a dropped Kindle) I decided I wanted to get the Kindle Fire for some of the magazines I am subscribed to as well as the NY Times. I have had a few stops and starts trying to figure out how to use a full touch screen electronic component. Also navigating the store and my library. Not all my kindle games are compatable with the fire. My review is less from a tech head perspective and more of just a user.I got it and it was automatically registered to my account since I bought it through Amazon. I was thrilled to see I was given some free tokens for audio books and games which I used. (I had a driving trip coming up the following week) The audio book played well through the aux outlet to the car stereo. I could see my pre-exisiting library on the cloud and select the items to download to my fire device. I got a little stuck 2 weeks into ownership trying to access netflix. It doesn't run on the silk browser. So I tried to download firefox which isn't available for Kindle although the app is in the Amazon store. This  ended up with a mayday call by accident (I was just trying to email customer service) and the rep was on video chat in less than a minute and helped me find the netflix app as well as answer another question about my Amazon watchlist navigation. That mayday app is worth the whole cost of the Kindle in my opinion. I have watched a number of videos, the streaming is great, the download aspect worked well. I could hear well, I didn't even feel the need to use headphones. I have shopped through the audio books, bookstore and videos. It has worked well, no complaints.A word of advice. I wavered between getting the 4G Verizon option or just wifi. At home I have wireless for my internet so it would be no issue for the Kindle. But I do travel occaisonally so I was concerned about that. Then I did the math If I bought 4G it is roughly an additional 80.00 on the cost and then I have to add it to my cell phone plan which runs an additional 20-25.00 a month. The I remembered virtually all 3G 4G smartphones have the hotspot capability. This includes mine and was something  I just discovered this year. So I skipped getting 4G.
